Happy New Year.
Welcome to TALK OF THE NATION.

I'm delighted to be here from the Foundation for the National Archives.
And, of course, the Emancipation Proclamation is an immensely important document, immensely more important moment in American history.
But as, of course, we learned most recently in the film ""Lincoln,"" it did not free all the slaves.
Well, absolutely.
The things that we learned in elementary school and high school about the Emancipation, was not quite the whole truth.
In fact, only the slaves who were in states that were in rebellion, where Lincoln actually really had no jurisdiction, were technically freed.

She wrote: Mr. President, it is my desire to be free to go to see my people on the Eastern Shore.
My mistress won't let me.
You will please let me know if we are free, and what I can do.
I write to you for advice.
Please send me word this week, or as soon as possible, and oblige.
Annie Davis.
